metadata.title: Lung Volume Reduction Surgery on Extracorporeal Life Support

sections.abstract: Lung volume reduction surgery improves exercise tolerance, lung function, and quality of life for selected patients with emphysema. Lung volume reduction surgery is well established for patients in a highly elective setting. It is, however, contraindicated in cases of acute cardiorespiratory failure. We present the case of a patient with severe emphysema who had acute respiratory failure and decompensated cor pulmonale requiring life-saving venovenoarterial extracorporeal life support after admission to the emergency unit. He underwent lung volume reduction surgery with intent to wean from extracorporeal life support. He had complete functional recovery after 4 months.
sections.methods: Single-patient case report. A 33-year-old man with severe, upper-lobe-predominant emphysema and decompensated cor pulmonale presented with acute respiratory failure. Due to persistent hemodynamic and respiratory failure, femorofemoral venoarterial ECLS was initiated, followed by an additional jugular venous cannula (venovenoarterial ECLS) for oxygenation. Sequential right- and left-sided upper-lobe LVRS via anterior thoracotomies was performed on consecutive days. ECLS was downgraded to femorojugular venovenous mode on postoperative day 5, with tracheostomy. Support was subsequently weaned.
sections.results: The patient was weaned from ECLS on day 8 and from mechanical ventilation on day 13 after the first LVRS. The tracheostomy was removed 3 weeks after LVRS, and the patient was discharged to rehabilitation 5 weeks after LVRS. At 4 months, the patient was free of respiratory symptoms. ABG on room air: pH 7.43; PaO2 9.9 kPa; PaCO2 5.3 kPa; SaO2 96%; HCO3- 26.3 mmol/L. 6MWT distance was 375 m (reduced due to postoperative left foot flexor paresis). PFT after bronchodilation: FVC 5.3 L (109%), FEV1 3.98 L (98%), FEV1/FVC 70%, TLC 7.47 L (108%), RV 2.1 L (118%), RV/TLC 28% (105%), DLCO 8.54 mmol/min/kPa (76%).

population.text: Adult with severe upper-lobe-predominant emphysema, acute respiratory failure, and decompensated cor pulmonale requiring extracorporeal life support.
inclusion_criteria: Acute respiratory failure with hypoxemia and hypercapnia
exclusion_criteria: None explicitly stated; elective LVRS had been deferred previously due to ongoing smoking

intervention.text: Sequential bilateral lung volume reduction surgery while on ECLS
intervention.details: Venoarterial ECLS via femorofemoral cannulation with additional jugular venous cannula (venovenoarterial). Right upper-lobe LVRS on day 1 and left upper-lobe LVRS on day 2 via anterior thoracotomies. Downgrade to femorojugular venovenous ECLS and tracheostomy on day 5. Weaning from ECLS by day 8 and from mechanical ventilation by day 13.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In a 33-year-old with severe emphysema and decompensated cor pulmonale on ECLS, sequential bilateral LVRS enabled weaning from ECLS by day 8 and ventilation by day 13, with marked improvement in lung function and gas exchange at 4 months.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Demonstrates feasibility of LVRS as a rescue strategy in highly selected patients on ECLS with acute respiratory failure and cor pulmonale.
